name: rosa-carolina
wildlife-value: It provides excellent cover year round. Hips are eaten by songbirds, quail, wild turkey and small mammals. Bumblebees, diggerbees, green metialic bees, Anthophorine bees (Anthopora spp.) syrphid flies, and beetles visit the flowers in search of pollen. Moth larva feed on the leaves. Leaves and stems are browsed by white-tailed deer and elk.
edibility: Remove the white, bitter base of the petals of the edible flowers before using to garnish desserts, freeze in ice cubes and float in punch.Â The petals can be used in syrup, jelly, butter, and spreads.  The hips are also edible.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Red fruit displays from August to October.
flower-description: 2 in., single, rich rose pink (rarely white) with bright yellow stamens and a pistil at the flat wide center. Fragrance is typical of roses, flowers appear from May to June on pedicles with glandular hairs. Green pointed sepals also have glandular hairs.
leaf-description: Alternate compound leaves with  oddly pinnate 5-7 ovate leaflets, with serrate margins (ocassionally 3 leaflets) with the central stem having hairs.   Leaflets are 2 inches long and 1 inch across.
stem-description: Prickles which are narrow and straight appear often in oppisite pairs or scattered on straight thin stems.  Young stems are smooth and green pink,  red turning brown as they mature.
uses: This plant was used by Native Americans for medicinal purposes.
